ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Exposure to the depths of Benjamin's critical oeuvre; openness to novel conceptual frameworks.
I got a great exposure to Benjamin's writing. Dr. North trained us to exercise close reading of the texts.

The course was an excellent introduction to the Benjaminian corpus from the perspective of critical method and a select number of critical "objects." I also developed my ability to deal with dense, difficult theoretical texts.
An in-depth journey with Benjamin. Every piece of his writing is treated not as a treatise but as the beginning of a philosophical method.
a deeper understanding of Benjamin scholarship on Benjamin new forms of critique

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Paul North's mastery of the subject matter and gift for eloquent explanation; the subject matter itself. Weaknesses: I wish we had met twice a week, rather than once. Perhaps two two-hour seminars, rather than one three-hour. We often tired after two hours.
I enjoy the structure of the course. I recommend that two students can lead discussions.

The major strength is that this seminar, unlike most seminars taught at Yale, allows for an extended engagement with a single body of work of an entire semester. At the beginning of each semester, Prof. North helpfully charted the territory for each week's concerns; much of the seminar was then dedicated to parsing out difficult passages and arguments and asking difficult questions of the text.
One major strength was the class length. It allowed us to maintain long discussions on difficult texts. One weakness was the size of the class. A smaller size would make the discussion even better.
Paul's philosophy is compatible with Benjamin's writing he takes the time that each text deserves.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Without hesitation. An extraordinary exposure to some of the most subtle and intricate thinking I have ever encountered.
Yes, I will. Benjamin is a very versatile thinker and can benefit students from a variety of fields.
yup. chance to learn benjamin and listen to prof north, as well as other students in the class was very rewarding and excellent.

I would recommend this to anyone who wants to increase their familiarity with and fluency in critical theory. The discussions can become rather difficult and conceptual, but the issues at stake are almost always relevant to our own intellectual and political moment.
Yes, but only if you are drawn towards Benjamin.
I would recommend this course to other students as Paul North gives a unique perspective on Walter Benjamin.
